baseline_groups.claim_summary: Employment-to-employment (EE) reallocation rate positively predicts nominal wage growth at the market-time level, persisting when controlling for UE transitions.
baseline_groups.notes: Three baseline variants report EE coeff on nominal earnings growth: (1) EE alone with market FE, (2) EE controlling for UE, (3) EE controlling for UE and UR. Horse race spec (baseline_ee_ue) is most canonical.

baseline_groups.claim_summary: UE transition rate predicts nominal wage growth but effect is weaker than EE when both included.
baseline_groups.notes: UE alone (baseline_ue) and UE coeff from horse race (baseline_ee_ue_ue).

baseline_groups.claim_summary: Unemployment rate predicts nominal wage growth when entered alone but adds little when EE and UE controlled.
baseline_groups.notes: UR alone with market FE. Secondary comparison variable.

global_notes: Paper tests relative predictive power of EE vs UE vs UR for wage growth using SIPP 1996-2013 market-time panels. G1 is primary claim. Several robustness specs identical to baseline_ee_ue (min_obs_10, min_obs_20, weighted, cluster/none). Demographic subgroup specs classified as core_sample; interaction heterogeneity specs as noncore_heterogeneity.
